moves.1. e4 d5 2. d4 c6 3. exd5 cxd5: my orginal intention was to play into classical caro-kann positions but you did well in keeping me on my toes. This is the caro-kann exchange varation which is fine for black.
moves.4. Nf3 Nc6 5. Bb5 Bd7 6. Nc3 Nf6 7. Bf4: good development so far white is only slightly better because of the his space advantage.
moves.7... e6: completing the caro-kann defensive structure with ...e6 very good for black. However, white has two major positional victories #1 strong and mobile pieces and creating a weakness on ...c6. The drawback of the exchange varation for white is that he has a weak centre. It is instructive how black manages to undermine it.
moves.8. O-O Bb4: intending to wreck whites pawn structure with Bxc3 which weakens whites control of the important d5 and e4 squares.
moves.9. a3: !? this provokes the ideal exchange for black. Because of his limited mobilty it is better to avoid exchanges and restrict the mobility even more for black. I would think Ne5 would be more to the point.
moves.9... Bxc3 10. bxc3: black is doing better now because is weakness on c6 is well covered whereas white's c3 and b5 are not. To add to this e4 is now available for a knight. Because e4 is now available the black knight the balance of power in the centre as shifted in black's favor.
moves.11. Bxc6: ?? the critcal mistake that completely abandon the centre.
moves.11... Bxc6: Bxc6 is a more active way to defend against a possible attack on d5 via c4
notice how black has complete control of d5 and e4 and the result is that white's center is gone.
moves.16. Ne5 O-O: I am willing to tolerate a doubled pawn weakness in order to gain complete dominance of the center.
moves.19. Rb1 Rxd4 20. Qh5 Rad8: never underestimate the power of controlling the center. Black threatens to play ...Rd5
moves.21. Rb7 g6 22. Qc5 Rd4d1: wins the rook because of the threat of a back rank mate
